all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Oh, I've been talking away and I've been muted. So, um, Michael and Tim, you've been stuck with me this entire meeting, haven't you? Can you hear me?

annotations.ask clarifying question: The speaker is checking if Michael and Tim can hear him, which is a request for confirmation and clarification.

annotations.express humor: The speaker makes a lighthearted comment about Michael and Tim being 'stuck' with him, suggesting a humorous tone.

all_data.speaker: Michael Burton
all_data.transcript: I don't see it that way at all.

annotations.express agreement: Michael disagrees with Robert's statement that Michael and Tim have been stuck with him during the meeting, implying he enjoyed the interaction, thus expressing agreement with a positive view of the interaction.

all_data.speaker: Timothy Sampson
all_data.transcript: Hasn't been a problem.

annotations.express agreement: Tim explicitly agrees with Michael's statement that Robert talking hasn't been a problem, indicating agreement with the sentiment that Robert's contributions have been valuable.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Um, so let's start uh with introducing ourselves. Um, again, I'll start. I'm Bob Bryan, professor uh at Baylor College of Medicine. And my interest is is in the gut brain axis and uh if you were here yesterday, you saw I was doing some stroke studies. But in addition to that, I've been doing studies with hypertension, uh, obstructive sleep apnea induced hypertension, cerebral small vessel disease or or vascular dementia. And we're finding uh the gut microbiome to have important roles in all of this.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker defines his role as a professor at Baylor College of Medicine and his research interest in the gut-brain axis, providing context for his expertise.
annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces his research on the gut microbiome's role in hypertension, sleep apnea-induced hypertension, cerebral small vessel disease, and vascular dementia, which are new topics in the conversation.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Okay.

annotations.None: This utterance does not fit into any of the codes provided.

all_data.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
all_data.transcript: I'll go next. Um, yeah, my name is Faranak Fattahi. I'm at UCSF. Uh my background is in stem cell and developmental biology and my lab basically uses IPSCs and embryonic stem cells to generate um various components of the peripheral nervous system including the enteric nerves and enteric glial cells. Um so we develop in vitro models of you know, cell cell interaction and how the nerves communicate with um the rest of the GI tract.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains their lab's work with IPSCs and embryonic stem cells to generate components of the peripheral nervous system, clarifying their research focus for the group.

all_data.speaker: Shikha Nangia
all_data.transcript: I can go next. My name is Shikha Nangia. I'm an associate professor in biomedical and chemical engineering at Syracuse University in New York. Uh, I'm a computational biophysicist, biochemist, uh trained as a chemist. Uh, we look at the interaction of uh neighboring cells at the molecular level, looking at tight junction architecture and uh proteins that are embedded on the cell surface. Um, and also I study bacterial cell membranes and bacterial porins, so how the metabolites go in and out of bacterial cells. So I have uh interest both in the blood brain barrier uh architecture and getting drugs into the brain as well as the bacterial cells. Um, so the this is the right uh session for me because we're talking about connecting these two aspects of my research and I'd like to contribute at the molecular level as much as I can to this work, which is very, very important. I'll stop there. Thank you.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is introducing herself and her research background, which involves explaining her expertise in computational biophysics, biochemistry, and the study of cell interactions at the molecular level.

annotations.express agreement: The speaker states that this is the right session for her because it connects two aspects of her research, indicating agreement with the session's focus.

annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses enthusiasm by stating that she'd like to contribute as much as she can to this work, which she considers very important.

all_data.speaker: Leah Pyter OSU
all_data.transcript: I'm Leah Pyter. I'm a associate professor at uh Ohio State University. I'm a neurobiologist and I'm interested in the potential role of the gut microbiome in cancer related behavioral comorbidities um due to tumor biology, stress, uh chemotherapy, things like that. Mostly do rodent modeling, but we also have studying breast cancer patients. Um, yeah, and I'm really interested in this topic.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is defining their role as a neurobiologist and their research interests related to the gut microbiome and cancer-related behavioral comorbidities.

annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses their enthusiasm by stating they are 'really interested in this topic', indicating excitement and encouragement.

all_data.speaker: Michael Burton
all_data.transcript: Hello, so I'm Michael Burton. I'm uh assistant professor uh and I am an I guess uh a neuroscientist where we look at the interaction between the nervous system um and the brain and so communication from the periphery to the brain. So kind of up my alley in the context of how you have um interactions or communication from the gut to the brain. So pretty excited about the conversation.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker defines their role as a neuroscientist who studies the interaction between the nervous system and the brain, specifically communication from the periphery to the brain.
annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses excitement about the conversation, indicating their interest in the topic.

all_data.speaker: Flavio Frohlich
all_data.transcript: Hello everyone. My name is Flavio. It's a pleasure to be with you. I'm at UNC at Chapel Hill. I study brain networks in a pre-clinical animal model, the ferret and then in humans from basic science to clinical trials focused on brain stimulation to modulate the activity patterns as treatments for psychiatric illnesses and I have a growing interest in understanding what actually cause all these illnesses uh which has led me to all of you.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains his research focus on brain networks, brain stimulation, and psychiatric illnesses, providing context for his interest in the group's discussion.
annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses pleasure in joining the group, indicating excitement about the collaboration.

all_data.speaker: Lawrence David
all_data.transcript: I'm Lawrence David. I'm at Duke University and down the street from Flavio. Uh, our lab works on diet based uh modulation of the gut microbiome and we have a growing interest in um gut brain and recently did a dietary intervention around a prebiotic trial and seeing its impact on behavior and cognition.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is defining their lab's area of expertise, which involves diet-based modulation of the gut microbiome and its impact on the gut-brain axis.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on their lab's work by mentioning a recent dietary intervention involving a prebiotic trial and its effects on behavior and cognition, building upon the initial introduction of their lab's focus on diet-based modulation of the gut microbiome.
annotations.present new idea: The speaker presents the new idea of a dietary intervention around a prebiotic trial and its impact on behavior and cognition, which is a specific project within their broader research area.

all_data.speaker: Harris Wang
all_data.transcript: I'm Harris Wang. I'm an uh Columbia University at the Medical Center. Um, uh my lab is focused on developing new genetic tools for to engineer uh microbiomes and uh understanding the spatial temporal organization of microbial communities um in the gut. Um, and uh yeah, we're we have some emerging interest in in trying to engineer um some of these probiotics uh for gut brain um modulation.

annotations.present new idea: Harris Wang introduces the idea of developing new genetic tools to engineer microbiomes and understanding the spatial temporal organization of microbial communities in the gut, which hasn't been explicitly mentioned by others yet.
annotations.expand on existing idea: He expands on the general topic of gut-brain modulation by mentioning his lab's emerging interest in engineering probiotics for this purpose, building upon the overall theme of the meeting.

all_data.speaker: Cesar de la Fuente UPenn
all_data.transcript: Hey everybody.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: The utterance is a greeting, which acknowledges the presence of everyone in the meeting.

all_data.speaker: Timothy Sampson
all_data.transcript: So my name is Tim Sampson and I'm an assistant professor at Emory and my lab uses uh mouse models to study microbiome interactions in neurodegenerative disorders, uh mostly Parkinson's and some Alzheimer's disease and as everybody has heard, I think I'm also doing a little bit on traumatic uh spinal cord injury and how the microbiome can affect uh neurogenesis in the gut uh after injury to promote recovery.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is introducing himself and his research interests, which involves defining the scope of his work with mouse models to study microbiome interactions in neurodegenerative disorders.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on his research interests by providing specific examples of neurodegenerative disorders he studies, such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease, building upon the initial introduction of his research focus.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Are we missing anyone?

annotations.encourage participation: Robert Bryan Jr. is checking if anyone else wants to introduce themselves, encouraging participation from those who haven't spoken yet.

all_data.speaker: Daren Ginete
all_data.transcript: I'll briefly introduce myself. My name is Daren and I'm the infectious disease fellow at Science Philanthropy Alliance. We support funders who are interested in basic science research and so I'm excited to observe in this breakout session.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker is introducing themself and their role at the Science Philanthropy Alliance, which explains their presence in the meeting.
annotations.express enthusiasm: The speaker expresses excitement about observing the breakout session, indicating a positive sentiment.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Great, welcome. Is that it? So everybody uh excuse me, it's late for me, but you're going to see me eating some lunch throughout this. Um, anyway, next item of business is a scribe. So anyone want to be a scribe?

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Robert acknowledges Daren's introduction, welcoming him to the session.
annotations.explaination: Robert acknowledges Daren's introduction, welcoming him to the session.

annotations.encourage participation: Robert is encouraging participation by asking if anyone wants to be a scribe for the meeting.
annotations.explaination: Robert is encouraging participation by asking if anyone wants to be a scribe for the meeting.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Don't be shy. You know, last time, last session, uh, Michael, I closed my eyes and pointed to the screen and that's Michael came up. So I might do the same thing this time if if uh no one volunteers.

annotations.encourage participation: Robert is trying to get someone to volunteer as a scribe by using humor and a threat of randomly assigning the task, which encourages participation.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: You know, Tim, I'm going to pick on you.

annotations.assign task: Robert is assigning the task of being the scribe to Tim, as he is picking on him to volunteer.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Would you do it?

annotations.assign task: Robert Bryan Jr. is asking Tim Sampson to be the scribe, continuing from the previous turns where he was trying to assign the task of scribe.

all_data.speaker: Timothy Sampson
all_data.transcript: I I do not mind. I'm happy to. Just need to get the folder open again. It closed.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Oh, have you uh have you done this before?

all_data.transcript: No.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: Okay. Great.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: So communications between the gut and the brain. And on this breakout group, we have uh a number of questions we can discuss. Um, let me just go ahead and read them. I don't know if you have that in in front of you or not. But what is the diversity of message that pass back and forth between the gut microbiome and the brain? Uh, okay, um, let's see here. Are these unidirectional or bidirectional channels of communication? Are there ways to perturb neuronal function to watch the microbial response? And finally, how can these communication signals be monitored, hijacked or interrupted to drive desired outcomes?
all_data.screenshare_content: The screen shared was a red and yellow sunset over a lake. The screen was then covered by a white sheet of paper, and then the sunset was visible again.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The phrase "communications between the gut and the brain" introduces the central topic of the breakout group, setting the stage for the subsequent discussion.
annotations.present new idea: The utterance introduces several questions for discussion, including the diversity of messages, directionality of communication, methods to perturb neuronal function, and ways to monitor or manipulate communication signals, which are all new ideas for the group to consider.

all_data.speaker: Shikha Nangia
all_data.transcript: Many disease models depend on which metabolite we are interested in. And so if we are talking about communication between the gut and the brain, I feel that the gateway is the cells and whether it's intercellular or intracellular would be very important to know.

annotations.present new idea: Shikha introduces the idea that the gateway for gut-brain communication is the cells and the importance of knowing if the communication is intercellular or intracellular.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Shikha supports her idea by mentioning that disease models depend on the metabolite of interest and relating it to gut-brain communication.

all_data.speaker: Robert Bryan Jr
all_data.transcript: What sort of techniques do you use to measure this breakdown passage?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Robert is asking for more details about the techniques used to measure the breakdown passage discussed by Shikha.

all_data.speaker: Shikha Nangia
all_data.transcript: So, we have so we study the molecular interactions at the tight junction level, which is caused by the proteins called claudins. And the blood brain barrier is made up of claudin 5, which is belongs to the family of claudins, but that is unique to the brain. So if you are looking for transport across that, we have studied the extracellular interactions between those claudin molecules and found out the pore sizes and the chemical specificity of the pore to figure out whether a cation, for example, is going to go easy or the anion. Even at the it's very iron selective and size selective. So those are the interactions we are looking at. But if you go to the gut and try to study the same tight junction interaction, that is made up of claudin 23 and claudin 11 and 3, which is very different from the brain. So what can go through the gut epithelial layer is different than what can go in the brain. So if the metabolites are going through, they have to be able to navigate that difference in the tight junctions. And that is just the paracellular aspect of it. The receptors and other things is a completely different story and which metabolite prefer going through the receptor needs to be known in my mind to to understand this this axis.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Shikha defines the tight junction level, claudins, blood-brain barrier, and their role in molecular transport, clarifying the mechanisms of metabolite passage between gut and brain.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Shikha provides evidence from her research on claudin interactions, pore sizes, and chemical specificity to explain the selective transport across the blood-brain barrier and gut epithelial layer.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Shikha elaborates on the previously mentioned importance of cellular gateways by detailing the molecular interactions at tight junctions and their role in selective transport of metabolites.

all_data.speaker: Timothy Sampson
all_data.transcript: So maybe I'm misunderstanding, but it sounds is it possible then to predict what type of metabolites are crossing a particular junction based on which tight junction proteins are disregulated at that moment in time?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Tim is asking for clarification on whether metabolite type prediction is possible based on tight junction protein regulation, demonstrating a need to confirm his understanding of Shikha's explanation.

all_data.speaker: Shikha Nangia
all_data.transcript: Yes, that can be done. But the question is that the metabolite library is vast and which one are the key ones that we are interested in. Uh and which ones have a receptor, known receptor and which ones don't. So those questions are unanswered and that's what I was trying to steer the conversation towards is are we interested in looking at how this communication happens and through which pathway. Uh and if it's through the blood or not. Because I was also hearing the nerve nerve interactions which I'm not aware of much of it. So that that's also that distinction there, like which is the blood driven one and which is not.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Shikha Nangia elaborates on Tim Sampson's question about predicting metabolite passage by highlighting the vastness of the metabolite library and the importance of identifying key metabolites and their receptors.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Shikha Nangia clarifies the direction of the conversation by asking whether the team is interested in how communication happens, through which pathway, and whether it's blood-driven or not, given the mention of nerve interactions.

all_data.speaker: Lawrence David
all_data.transcript: Sorry.

annotations.None: No code from the codebook applies to this single-word utterance.

all_data.speaker: Harris Wang
all_data.transcript: I guess I just following up on on that, you know, I think I'm pretty interested in in also the you know, the brain to the gut or potentially in in other from peripheral nerves to the gut. Um and it seems like there's been, you know, some recent studies on like, you know, looking at traumatic brain injury and and its effects on the microbiome and it seems like there's some inflammatory responses, but I'm not this is not my area, so I'm curious whether people have any thoughts as to what what are the mechanisms associated with this is it through the the vagal nerves um in a bidirectional fashion. And also there's been some past studies on looking at, you know, peripheral nerve stimulation for immune modulation and and I don't think anyone's I'm not aware of any studies looking at how that might affect like, you know, the microbiome and so I wonder if people have any thoughts about that.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Harris Wang expands on Shikha Nangia's discussion of gut-brain communication by focusing on the brain-to-gut direction and peripheral nerve involvement.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Harris Wang mentions recent studies on traumatic brain injury and its effects on the microbiome as evidence of brain-gut communication.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Harris Wang asks for thoughts on the mechanisms of brain-gut communication, specifically regarding vagal nerve involvement and peripheral nerve stimulation's effect on the microbiome.
annotations.encourage participation: Harris Wang concludes by asking for others' thoughts on the topic, encouraging participation from other researchers in the discussion.

all_data.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
all_data.transcript: So the effect on the microbiome interestingly could be very indirect too because if your neuromodulation affects the motility, the movement of the gut, then that could affect the composition of the microbiome. Um and so many brain interventions like thinking about medications that are given to patients with neurological disorders, they also disrupt motility patterns, they you know, lead to constipation or diarrhea. And so how does that then affect the microbiome? Um it could be completely indirect just to overall physiology of the gut.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Farahnak expands on the previous discussion of brain-gut interactions by suggesting that neuromodulation's impact on the microbiome could be indirect, through its effects on gut motility.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Farahnak provides examples of how brain interventions, such as medications for neurological disorders, can disrupt motility and thus potentially affect the microbiome.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Farahnak poses a question about how the microbiome is affected by changes in gut motility caused by brain interventions.

all_data.speaker: Timothy Sampson
all_data.transcript: Yeah, that's something that we're seeing in our spinal cord injury models. And so after at least in mice models when they when they're injured, it's they lose some enteric neurons. And so there's this drastic slowing that happens of of gut motility. But what is interesting is the microbiome then doesn't change until so that slowing happens really early with two to four days and then microbiome composition doesn't shift until two weeks later significantly. Um and then really solidified like four four weeks later. But so so there's definitely that top down effect that's happening to shift the microbiome. But it doesn't necessarily mean then that that new microbiome's composition doesn't then affect the affect the host in some way.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Tim provides evidence from his team's spinal cord injury mice models, showing that gut motility slows down within 2-4 days post-injury, but microbiome composition changes significantly only after two weeks.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Tim expands on Farahnak's point about the indirect effects of neuromodulation on the microbiome by providing specific examples from his spinal cord injury models.
annotations.present new idea: Tim introduces the new idea that while a top-down effect shifts the microbiome, the new microbiome composition might, in turn, affect the host.

all_data.speaker: Lawrence David
all_data.transcript: Did you not see any acute changes, I guess? Sorry.

annotations.ask clarifying question: Lawrence David asks Tim Sampson to clarify whether acute changes were observed in microbiome composition after spinal cord injury in mice, given the later significant shifts mentioned by Tim.
annotations.express humor: Lawrence David uses "I guess" and "sorry", which can be interpreted as self-deprecating humor, possibly to soften the directness of the question or to downplay any perceived challenge to Tim's findings.

all_data.speaker: Lawrence David
all_data.transcript: See, see no acute changes in the microbiome?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Lawrence David asks for clarification on whether there were any immediate changes observed in the microbiome following spinal cord injury in mice, referring back to Tim Sampson's description of delayed microbiome shifts.
